Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: The team awaits a clarification before progressing with a shared task.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: A notice has been posted about an optional training session happening next week.
Story: I stared at my phone, the screen lighting up with yet another message from my colleague, Mark. The team was waiting for my input on the project plan, and I knew they couldn’t move forward until I clarified a few details. I could almost feel their impatience through the screen, the unspoken expectation that I’d respond quickly, as I always tried to do. But the noise of the construction site pressed in around me—shouts, the clang of metal, the constant hum of machinery. My foreman had just posted a notice about an optional training session next week, and he’d made it clear that those who attended would be seen as more committed to the team. I wanted to show I was dedicated, not just another guy punching the clock. But I also didn’t want to let my office team down. My phone buzzed again, and I felt the weight of both worlds pulling at me, each demanding my attention, each expecting me to be fully present. I stood there, torn, the decision looming over me, unsure which role I was about to disappoint.
